awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: REU Site: Security Printing and Anti-counterfeit Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
The South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, along with partner organizations, South Dakota State University, and the University of South Dakota will offer an innovative Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) Site focused on interdisciplinary research dedicated to Security Printing and Anti-Counterfeiting Technology (SPACT), to a diverse cohort of undergraduate students.  Counterfeiting is a growing issue in the U.S., posing serious economic, safety and national security concerns and impacting a wide variety of industries (e.g. pharmaceutics, semiconductors). REU participants will engage in interdisciplinary collaborative research that pairs physical scientists and engineers with social and behavioral scientists. This convergent approach is crucial for addressing and disrupting the complexity inherent to modern illicit supply networks. 

During this 10-week summer research experience, 10 REU students will conduct research on transformative anti-counterfeiting technology. SPACT is a field which demands development in four key areas: (i) advanced materials, (ii) advanced manufacturing and patterning, (ii) detection and encryption, and (iv) social/behavior science and systems engineering. The key objectives of the program are to (1) conduct transformative research in a collaborative, interdisciplinary environment, and (2) provide STEM professional development opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate students, with a focus on Tribal Colleges and other institutions with limited STEM research opportunities. A talented team of faculty mentors from a variety of STEM disciplines, with a wide spectrum of experience and backgrounds, will implement a program in SPACT by engaging REU participants in interdisciplinary collaborative research that pairs physical scientists and engineers with social and behavioral scientists. Students will also participate in a highly integrated professional development and technical communications program designed to stimulate professional development and the development of research skills necessary to succeed in the 21st century. The faculty, alongside industry leaders, will deliver training seminars to broaden the students' existing academic training in the relevant SPACT areas. The long-term goal is to provide a diverse group of STEM researchers with the training and skills needed to pursue graduate studies at the highest levels and to advance the developing field of SPACT.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
During the summers of 2019 and 2021-2023, 36 undergraduate students conducted research focused on Security Printing and Anti-Counterfeiting Technology (SPACT). The key objectives were to (1) conduct transformative research in a collaborative, interdisciplinary environment, and (2) provide STEM professional development opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate students, with a minimum of 20% NA students, 40% female students, and 50% from universities with limited STEM research opportunities.

 

Intellectual Merit

SPACT REU students have produced 15 national/international conference presentations (13 undergraduate 1st author), and 36 regional conference presentations (35 undergraduate 1st author). Furthermore, one patent applications was submitted as a result of the REU research activities. The PIs and REU participants have communicated Site activities through regional and nationwide news outlets in the form of television, newspaper, and magazines. This has been an effective method to increase the public awareness of the SPACT REU program. Furthermore, SPACT REU students were encouraged to share their REU success stories with various outreach programs. The SPACT REU program has had a profound impact on undergraduate research within SD. In this regard, in 2014 the PIs requested support from the SD EPSCoR program to organize and lead the first “SD Undergraduate Research Symposium” at the state capital, Pierre, SD. The annual event has now showcased over 1550 undergraduate research posters in the past ten years.

 

Broader Impacts

The most critical desired outcome from this REU program is to provide a unique research training opportunity to a diverse group of undergraduate students in hopes they may be influenced to attend graduate school in STEM fields or otherwise pursue employment in STEM disciplines. The SPACT REU site was successful in recruiting talented and engaged undergraduate researchers with participants coming from 17 different institutions, representing 9 states. The program was also successful in recruiting and engaging a diverse group of REU participants, evidenced by 22% and 53% underrepresented minority and female student representation, respectively. Importantly, 22% of the REU participants where Native American. Each year two research projects were specifically developed to recruit and engage Native American students while addressing counterfeiting problems that affect the Native American community. Furthermore, 61% of REU participants were from universities with limited STEM research opportunities. The Site also had a significant focus on engaging a diverse group of students with respect to educational background. In this regard, 39% of REU participants were first or second year college students. To ensure a beneficial research experience for these students, the PIs have worked with faculty mentors to develop research projects and mentoring activities which allow the students to flourish within the context of their prior training. Finally, as an interdisciplinary program, we strive to attract students from a wide range of STEM disciplines. REU participants were from 11 different STEM disciplines. The REU faculty have provided continued mentoring of past REU participants beyond their summer research experience. This included career mentoring as well as monitoring student persistence toward their undergraduate degree and career choice (which includes graduate school). 36 REU students have participated in the program to date and 28 of these students have now graduated with a B.S. degree in their chosen STEM discipline. Among these, 46% are currently enrolled in or have completed graduate school (3 Ph.D., 9 M.S.) or professional school (1) while 43% are working in STEM industries.
